items.title: Why Navalny dart frog poison announcement was deliberately timed
items.standfirst: It is no coincidence that the UK and its allies chose a security conference in Munich to accuse the Kremlin of killing Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny with dart frog poison.
items.content: It is no coincidence that the UK and its allies chose a security conference in Munich to accuse the Kremlin of killing Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny with dart frog poison.

items.title: Russia killed opposition leader Alexei Navalny using dart frog toxin, UK says

items.content: There is no innocent explanation for the toxin being found in samples taken from Navalny's body, Foreign Office says.

items.title: Russia fatally 'poisoned' Putin critic Navalny with rare toxin, UK says
items.standfirst: Five European countries accused Russia of "poisoning" opposition leader Alexei Navalny using a rare toxin found in South American dart frogs, according to a joint statement issued Saturday. A leading critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin, Navalny died in an Arctic penal colony in February 2024. France24 correspondent Benedicte Paviot reports the latest from London.
items.content: Five European countries accused Russia of "poisoning" opposition leader Alexei Navalny using a rare toxin found in South American dart frogs, according to a joint statement issued Saturday. A leading critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin, Navalny died in an Arctic penal colony in February 2024. France24 correspondent Benedicte Paviot reports the latest from London.

items.title: European states accuse Russia of Navanlny poisoning
items.standfirst: Five European countries, including Britain, France and Germany, accused Russia on Saturday of having poisoned jailed opposition figure Alexei Navalny with a rare and lethal toxin in 2024, speaking on the margins of the Munich Security Conference, as the United Kingdom, Sweden, France, Germany and Netherlands said in a joint statement that analyses of samples from Navalny’s body left them confident he had been poisoned, following the death of the outspoken critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin in an Arctic prison in February 2024 while he was serving a 19-year sentence. France24 correspondent Nick Holdsworth reports from Munich.
items.content: Five European countries, including Britain, France and Germany, accused Russia on Saturday of having poisoned jailed opposition figure Alexei Navalny with a rare and lethal toxin in 2024, speaking on the margins of the Munich Security Conference, as the United Kingdom, Sweden, France, Germany and Netherlands said in a joint statement that analyses of samples from Navalny’s body left them confident he had been poisoned, following the death of the outspoken critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin in an Arctic prison in February 2024 while he was serving a 19-year sentence. France24 correspondent Nick Holdsworth reports from Munich.

items.title: Why do European governments say Navalny was poisoned? #world

The chemical identified, epibatidine, is not a commonplace…
items.content: New analysis points to a rare, lethal toxin European foreign ministries in several countries say tests on samples from the late Russian opposition figure revealed traces of a rare and deadly toxin derived from poison dart frogs. items.title: Russia killed Alexei Navalny with frog toxin, UK and four European allies say
items.standfirst: Intelligence agencies say deadly toxin in skin of Ecuador dart frogs found in Navalny’s body and highly likely resulted in his death• What is dart frog toxin, which is said to have been used to kill Alexei Navalny?Alexei Navalny, the Russian opposition leader, was killed by dart frog poison administered by the Russian state two years ago, a multi-intelligence agency inquiry has found, according to a statement released by five countries, the UK, France, Germany, Sweden and the Netherlands.The US was not one of the intelligence agencies making the claim. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: 5 European nations say Alexei Navalny was poisoned and blame the Kremlin
items.standfirst: In a joint statement, the foreign ministries of the U.K., France, Germany, Sweden and the Netherlands say Navalny was poisoned by Russia with a lethal toxin derived from the skin of poison dart frogs.
items.content: In a joint statement, the foreign ministries of the U.K., France, Germany, Sweden and the Netherlands say Navalny was poisoned by Russia with a lethal toxin derived from the skin of poison dart frogs.(Image credit: Alexander Zemlianichenko)

items.title: Rubio says US and Europe 'belong together' despite tensions
items.standfirst: The US secretary of state reassures European leaders that the Trump administration backs the transatlantic alliance.
items.content: The US secretary of state reassures European leaders that the Trump administration backs the transatlantic alliance.

items.title: Rubio says US and Europe "belong together"
items.standfirst: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio sought to assuage European leaders' worries about fraying ties with Washington as he addressed the Munich Security Conference on Saturday, telling the annual gathering that Europe and the US "belong together" and that Washington wants to "revitalise" the transatlantic alliance. France24 journalist Andrew Hilliar explains.
items.content: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio sought to assuage European leaders' worries about fraying ties with Washington as he addressed the Munich Security Conference on Saturday, telling the annual gathering that Europe and the US "belong together" and that Washington wants to "revitalise" the transatlantic alliance. France24 journalist Andrew Hilliar explains.

items.title: Marco Rubio has warmer words for Europe weeks after Trump's harsh Davos comments
items.standfirst: Secretary of State Marco Rubio spoke at the Munich Security Conference on Saturday in an apparent effort to paper over cracks in the relationship between the U.S. and Europe, though foreign diplomats were less convinced that real change would follow
items.content: Secretary of State Marco Rubio spoke at the Munich Security Conference on Saturday in an apparent effort to paper over cracks in the relationship between the U.S. and Europe, though foreign diplomats were less convinced that real change would follow

items.title: Munich Security talks: Rubio says US wants to "revitalise" transatlantic alliance
items.standfirst: Marco Rubio’s address at the Munich Security Conference marked a more conciliatory stance for the U.S., following Vice President JD Vance’s harsh critique of Europe last year for ignoring an internal “threat,” shirking its defense responsibilities, and allowing left-wing influence in cultural matters. Although Rubio still encouraged European allies to consider policies akin to Donald Trump’s America, his speech clearly aimed to ease tensions and mend transatlantic relations. Senior Fellow at Scowcroft Center for Strategy and Security, Elisabeth Brown, tells us more.
items.content: Marco Rubio’s address at the Munich Security Conference marked a more conciliatory stance for the U.S., following Vice President JD Vance’s harsh critique of Europe last year for ignoring an internal “threat,” shirking its defense responsibilities, and allowing left-wing influence in cultural matters. Although Rubio still encouraged European allies to consider policies akin to Donald Trump’s America, his speech clearly aimed to ease tensions and mend transatlantic relations. Senior Fellow at Scowcroft Center for Strategy and Security, Elisabeth Brown, tells us more.

items.title: US urges stronger transatlantic alliance at Munich Security Conference

Although Rubio still encouraged European allies to consider policies akin to Donald Trump’s America, his speech clearly aimed to ease tensions and mend transatlantic relations. Antonia Kerrigan reports.
items.content: Marco Rubio’s address at the Munich Security Conference marked a more conciliatory stance for the U.S., following Vice President JD Vance’s harsh critique of Europe last year for ignoring an internal “threat,” shirking its defense responsibilities, and allowing left-wing influence in cultural matters. Although Rubio still encouraged European allies to consider policies akin to Donald Trump’s America, his speech clearly aimed to ease tensions and mend transatlantic relations. items.title: Limited government shutdown likely to linger for at least 10 days as Congress takes break
items.standfirst: 13% of federal civilian workforce is affected, although DHS – which spurred budget standoff – remains fundedA limited US government shutdown came into effect on Saturday – the third of Donald Trump’s second term – after negotiations between the White House and Democrats in Congress failed to agree on new restrictions for federal immigration agents.The shutdown affects about 13% of the federal civilian workforce and is confined to agencies under the umbrella of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), including the Transportation Security Administration (TSA), which screens airline passengers. Continue reading...

items.title: Budget standoff over immigration shuts down US Department of Homeland Security
items.standfirst: A prolonged impasse between US lawmakers over immigration enforcement ensnared the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) in a partial government shutdown on Saturday, with Democrats in Congress vowing to withhold funding until major changes are enacted in the wake of two fatal shootings by federal immigration agents in Minneapolis.
items.content: A prolonged impasse between US lawmakers over immigration enforcement ensnared the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) in a partial government shutdown on Saturday, with Democrats in Congress vowing to withhold funding until major changes are enacted in the wake of two fatal shootings by federal immigration agents in Minneapolis.

Reported by Reuters Top News, Guardian World, BBC Top Stories

items.title: How did Brazil win its first Winter Olympic gold? #sports
items.standfirst: A historic run at Bormio that reshaped the Winter Games Lucas Pinheiro Braathen produced a decisive final run in the men's giant slalom at the Milan‑Cortina Olympics to claim gold in Bormio, Italy — the first Winter Olympic medal ever won by an athlete representing a South American nation.…
items.content: A historic run at Bormio that reshaped the Winter Games Lucas Pinheiro Braathen produced a decisive final run in the men's giant slalom at the Milan‑Cortina Olympics to claim gold in Bormio, Italy — the first Winter Olympic medal ever won by an athlete representing a South American nation.…

items.title: Why did Lucas Pinheiro Braathen make history? #sports
items.standfirst: A landmark victory that widened winter sport geography Lucas Pinheiro Braathen produced one of the most unexpected and consequential results of these Winter Games when he won the men’s giant slalom, delivering South America its first ever medal — and it was gold. His two run performance in Bormio…
items.content: A landmark victory that widened winter sport geography Lucas Pinheiro Braathen produced one of the most unexpected and consequential results of these Winter Games when he won the men’s giant slalom, delivering South America its first ever medal — and it was gold. His two run performance in Bormio…

items.title: Brazil’s Pinheiro Braathen wins gold – and South America’s first Winter Olympics medal
items.standfirst: Norwegian-born skier storms to historic slalom gold‘Your difference is your superpower,’ says 25-year-old As the snow fell in Bormio, and the fog settled in, Lucas Pinheiro Braathen made history by becoming the first South American to win a Winter Olympic medal. Then, as the realisation that he had won gold for Brazil in the men’s giant slalom, he collapsed to the floor and allowed the tears to flow.“I just hope that Brazilians look at this and truly understand that your difference is your superpower,” he said, still sobbing away. “It may show up in your skin or in the way you dress. But I hope this inspires every kid out there who feels a bit different to trust who you are.” Continue reading...
items.content: Norwegian-born skier storms to historic slalom gold‘Your difference is your superpower,’ says 25-year-old As the snow fell in Bormio, and the fog settled in, Lucas Pinheiro Braathen made history by becoming the first South American to win a Winter Olympic medal. Then, as the realisation that he had won gold for Brazil in the men’s giant slalom, he collapsed to the floor and allowed the tears to flow.“I just hope that Brazilians look at this and truly understand that your difference is your superpower,” he said, still sobbing away. “It may show up in your skin or in the way you dress. But I hope this inspires every kid out there who feels a bit different to trust who you are.” Continue reading...

clusters.title: French prosecutors to set up special team to review Epstein files
clusters.neutral_headline: French prosecutors to set up special team to review Epstein files
bullet_summary: Reported by Guardian World, France24

items.title: French prosecutors to set up special team to review Epstein files
items.standfirst: Magistrates will analyse evidence that could implicate French nationals and re-examine case of Jean-Luc BrunelThe Paris prosecutor’s office on Saturday announced it was setting up a special team of magistrates to analyse evidence that could implicate French nationals in the crimes of the convicted US sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.With Epstein’s known circle extending to prominent French figures after the release of documents by the US authorities, the prosecutor’s office said it would also thoroughly re-examine the case of former French modelling agency executive Jean-Luc Brunel, a close associate of the US financier, who died in custody in 2022. Continue reading...
items.content: Magistrates will analyse evidence that could implicate French nationals and re-examine case of Jean-Luc BrunelThe Paris prosecutor’s office on Saturday announced it was setting up a special team of magistrates to analyse evidence that could implicate French nationals in the crimes of the convicted US sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.With Epstein’s known circle extending to prominent French figures after the release of documents by the US authorities, the prosecutor’s office said it would also thoroughly re-examine the case of former French modelling agency executive Jean-Luc Brunel, a close associate of the US financier, who died in custody in 2022. Continue reading...

items.title: French prosecutors announce special team to analyse Epstein files
items.standfirst: The Paris prosecutor's office on Saturday announced it was setting up a special team to analyse files relating to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and investigate suspected crimes involving French nationals. As part of that initiative, they will be reopening their files on the late Jean-Luc Brunel, a former French modelling agency executive.
items.content: The Paris prosecutor's office on Saturday announced it was setting up a special team to analyse files relating to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and investigate suspected crimes involving French nationals. As part of that initiative, they will be reopening their files on the late Jean-Luc Brunel, a former French modelling agency executive.

items.title: Barack Obama publicly states support for anti-ICE demonstrators in Minneapolis
items.standfirst: Speaking with progressive YouTuber, former US president stressed ‘unprecedented nature’ of agency’s actionsBarack Obama publicly gave his support to demonstrators in Minneapolis for standing up to the “unprecedented nature” of the Immigrations and Customs Enforcement (ICE) operation in Minnesota.Speaking in an interview with progressive YouTuber Brian Tyler Cohen on Saturday, the former president discussed the power that US citizens hold when standing up for the values they believe in and his hopes for the next generation of American leaders. Continue reading...

clusters.title: American speedskater Jordan Stolz wins second Olympic gold with 500-meter race victory
clusters.neutral_headline: American Jordan Stolz wins 2nd speedskating gold at Winter Olympics
bullet_summary: Reported by NPR News, CBS News

items.title: American speedskater Jordan Stolz wins second Olympic gold with 500-meter race victory
items.standfirst: With the win, Stolz joins Eric Heiden as the only skaters to take gold in both the 500 and 1,000 at the same Olympics.
items.content: With the win, Stolz joins Eric Heiden as the only skaters to take gold in both the 500 and 1,000 at the same Olympics.(Image credit: Ben Curtis)

items.title: American Jordan Stolz wins 2nd speedskating gold at Winter Olympics
items.standfirst: It is Jordan Stolz's second gold medal of the 2026 Winter Games, breaking a world record.
items.content: It is Jordan Stolz's second gold medal of the 2026 Winter Games, breaking a world record.

items.title: Zelenskyy says Ukraine, not Russia, is facing pressure to make concessions to end war

items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and US Secretary of State Marco Rubio hint at difficulties in next week's talks.

clusters.title: Opinion: Disqualified but not forgotten
clusters.neutral_headline: The war dead pictured on banned Ukrainian athlete's helmet
bullet_summary: Reported by NPR News, BBC World

items.title: Opinion: Disqualified but not forgotten
items.standfirst: A Ukrainian athlete was disqualified from competition this week by the International Olympic Committee because his helmet had images of other Ukrainian athletes killed in Russia's war on his country.
items.content: A Ukrainian athlete was disqualified from competition this week by the International Olympic Committee because his helmet had images of other Ukrainian athletes killed in Russia's war on his country.(Image credit: Al Bello/Getty Images)

items.title: The war dead pictured on banned Ukrainian athlete's helmet
items.standfirst: Vladyslav Heraskevych's helmet depicts fellow athletes who have been killed since Russia's full-scale invasion of his country.
items.content: Vladyslav Heraskevych's helmet depicts fellow athletes who have been killed since Russia's full-scale invasion of his country.

clusters.title: Second US carrier heads to Middle East
clusters.neutral_headline: Second US carrier heads to Middle East
bullet_summary: Reported by France24, Sky News World

items.title: Second US carrier heads to Middle East
items.standfirst: US envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner are set to hold talks with Iran in Geneva on Tuesday, as Donald Trump told reporters on Friday that regime change would be the best possible outcome for the country, remarks that come as a second US aircraft carrier is redeployed toward the Middle East from the Caribbean, a journey expected to take at least a week. Peter O'Brien reports.
items.content: US envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner are set to hold talks with Iran in Geneva on Tuesday, as Donald Trump told reporters on Friday that regime change would be the best possible outcome for the country, remarks that come as a second US aircraft carrier is redeployed toward the Middle East from the Caribbean, a journey expected to take at least a week. Peter O'Brien reports.

items.title: Trump says Iran regime change would be the 'best thing that could happen'
items.standfirst: Donald Trump says regime change in Iran "would be the best thing that could happen" as a second US aircraft carrier is deployed to the Middle East.
items.content: Donald Trump says regime change in Iran "would be the best thing that could happen" as a second US aircraft carrier is deployed to the Middle East.

items.title: Why is the U.S. sending another aircraft carrier to the Middle East? #world
items.standfirst: Reinforcing presence as tensions with Iran escalate The White House has ordered a second U.S. aircraft carrier strike group to the Middle East as part of a broader push to deter Iran amid heightened concerns about its nuclear program and regional activity. Officials described the move as a surge…

items.title: Second U.S. aircraft carrier is being sent to the Middle East as Iran tensions remain high
items.standfirst: The USS Ford Carrier Strike Group has been notified that they are leaving the Caribbean and headed to the Middle East, according to two U.S. officials familiar with the decision.
items.content: The USS Ford Carrier Strike Group has been notified that they are leaving the Caribbean and headed to the Middle East, according to two U.S. officials familiar with the decision.
